b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: shouldn't the part about fetching profile URL say split on whitespace and then resolve each resulting token and fetch those?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:28): html4 only allowed one url
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:28): and html5 doesn't allow any
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: when HTML5 did allow profile, it allowed many URLs
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:28): (some people think that was a bug in HTML4)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): yeah, back when i didn't realise that profile="" sucked, i was going to expand it as suggested in some html4 comments
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:29): didn't some spec at some point allow multiple profiles?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:29): one of the XHTMLs?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): but turns out the bug is having profile="" at all
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): html4 mentions that profile="" in future might be expanded to take multiple urls
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:29): wonders if gmpg.org get a lot of automated profile fetches
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:29): really dislikes the idea of <main> or <content>
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:29): http://philip.html5.org/data/profile-values-2.txt
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:29): Seems people like multiple URLs
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:29): (A few people, anyway)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: but is anyone fetching them?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: isn't that an unscientific way to address <main>? :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): can't we get people to just use <div> instead of <main>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): the element is completely meaningless
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:30): copies and pastes one of the URLs into his browser
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): it has less meaning than <div>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:30): really likes the idea of <main> :)
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:30): Someone is fetching them now!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): it's as bad as <di>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It improves source readbility and will prevent misuse of sectioning elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:30): in fact it's worse than <di>
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: a future version of Opera Mobile could use it for the skip to content feature
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you can already skip to content! it adds _nothing_ for skip to content.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:31): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, come to think of it, I like <di> too, although the compat story is not nearly as good with <di>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:31): I also suspect that it will help with "skip to content" even though that is already theoretically possible
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:31): preventing misuse is its only redeeming feature
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:31): it seems to be a common pattern to wrap the main content in an element, and it seems to be a recurring question how to do that with HTML5
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:31): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: it adds the same thing to skip to content that rel=next adds to Fast Forward
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: no, it doesn't. we already have that today.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you can unambiguously tell where the content starts today.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: after </header>?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:32): (I didn't know that <div> was the party line answer to that until recently)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:32): see my e-mail
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:32): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: <div> is the element to use to wrap anything without adding semantics
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:32): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Using subtractive mechanisms to identify main content strikes me as more fragile than explicit mechanisms

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:33): I think 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e would say the first piece of content in <body> that's not one of the special non-main elements is how to skip to main

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:33): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: it's not substractive. You just keep skipping until you find the first element you're not skipping. It's more resilient than <main> because it lets you do it multiple times, regardless of nesting.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:33): in fact it's better because right now you get "skip to next interesting content" instead of "skip to main content", which is a subset

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:34): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It's subtractive in the sense that :the main content is all the content except that which is a descendant of {some list of elements}"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:34): maybe we just need to stick <div>s in a bunch of examples, if people are all obsessing about styling their contents for some reason
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:34): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'm pretty sure that evangalism woin't work any more than it does for accessibility

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:35): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: what you're saying then is that the <main> proposal actually is a negative semantic, it says, "everything not in this element is not important"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:35): I really don't see the harm in giving people what they want here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:35): which is even worse
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:35): how are people going to learn about <main>?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:36): The same way they learn about <section> i.e. from loosely worded, slightly inaccurate, blog posts

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:36): I think it just seems oddly non-parallel to people for everything but the main content to have a designated element, though I admit that pattern is found in other places in HTML on a smaller scale
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:36): well let's have blog posts about <div>
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:37): &quot 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e encourages people to use <div> more"
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:37): never thought I'd see the day :-)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:37): i really view this as exactly the same as <di>. It adds nothing semantically, it's only needed for styling if at all, and what it really does is add lots of possible ways for people to screw things up even more.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:37): A blog post that says "use <section> instead of <div> to mark up structure in HTML 5" will lead to the kind of misuse that we're seeing
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:38): And I have written a blog post telling people not to use <section> where they mean <div>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it does add something
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): anyway gotta go
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it would map to role=main

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:38): the current answer to what to use for the main content is actually "<div> or <article> depending on what you're doing or maybe <section> or maybe you don't need a special element at all"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:38): I've done the evangalism thing
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:39): which is too complicated
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:40): I would rather remove <article> and have <main> than have <section> and <article> but not <main>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:40): +1
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:40): Since people find the whole <section>/<article> thing rather confusing
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:40): I was thinking of proposing that actually, initially
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:41): there is the blog case where you'd have multiple <article>s inside <main>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:42): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: I think <article> is a good idea and I am happy to keep it. But I'm not convinced it will be used correctly
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:42): not sure how relevant that is, but bloggers are particularly fond of making pretty structural markup it seems
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:42): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: if both <main> and <article> existed, what errors do you think would be likely?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:43): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: Same as if <main> doesn't exist; people will use <article> where they mean <section>
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:43): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: in what cases do you think people would say <article> instead of <section>

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:43): (the point of removing it would jsut be to reduce the language surface and so the number of things to get confused about. It is only tangentially related to the <main> element)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:44): (except insofar as one should be able to suggest something to remove when adding something to keep the overall language tractable)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:44): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: you made it sound like a choice between <article> and <main> - just trying to understand your thinking on this
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:45): I imagine the difference between an article and a section of an article (or section in general) is clear
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:45): are you worried people will use <article> for article excerpts/summaries that are not truly full articles?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:46): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: There have been a few questions along the lines of "how do I nest <article> and <section> relative to one another" as well as "can I use <article> for a synopsis of an article"

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:46): what confuses me somewhat is when to use <section> vs <div> - some people have said you should only use <section> for its effect on the outline algorithm, but the spec also says applications can have <sections>, yet it's surely nonsensical to have an outline of an application UI
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:47): So whilst <article> seems clear enough to me in theory I am not sure that in the real world it will ever get treated differently to <section> by UAs
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:48): (I should state that I am more than happy to leave <article> in. I just don't think it's essential)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): learns that new Foo does stuff in JS without ()

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:48): (my favorite example on this is Google Calendar, which clearly if you look at it has visually identifiable "sections", but it would not really make sense to present those as an outline)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: Would it make sense if clicking on the heading in the outline view focused the first focusable child of that section?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): doesn't use Google calendar
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:50): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: you don't have to use it as such to get a look at what its main UI looks like
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:50): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: the idea of an outline view of an application UI just strikes me as a category error
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): Maybe for some webpages you are so far over into application land that document semantics don't make much sense
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:52): But there are a big class of pages, even those with some application-like behaviour, where headings and outlines and so on do make sense
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:52): so maybe you can say not to use <section> in that case, but that's not what the draft says at the moment
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:53): The other question is "would an outlineish view help AT users?"

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:54): I don't think an outline of GMail makes sense, even though in some sense the search area, the folder list, the currently viewed folder, the chat box and the contact list are separate sections
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:54): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: That seems sort of helpful to me
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:55): I can imagine that if I was using AT I would like the ability to jump straight to the chat box
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:55): And calling each different bit of the UI a "section" and giving each a heading seems like a reasonable way to achieve that
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:55): maybe, but I don't think native apps with different areas of the UI expose it in a form resembling a document outline
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:56): Right, I don't know what native apps do with AT.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:56): I would guess giving each of those sections a heading is something Google would not be up for, since it would mess up the layout
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:56): They could always hide the heading
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:57): Native applications like Lightroom have a very clealy define concept of "sections"

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:58): I believe on Mac OS X with VoiceOver, you can just cycle through the focusable controls, and there is no jumping around sections of the app; but I have not tried a super complicated app
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (12:10): not allowing multiple URIs in head/@profile is a known bug in HTML4, and if HTML5 defines it it should do it properly
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:11): is it in html4 errata?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (12:12): it should have been, but there was nobody working on errata; we had the discussion on the HTML WG mailing list around April I think.
